questions.text: A patient presented with multiple skin colored firm nodules over the back and trunk. The patient had few dark colored patches over the back. Patient's father complained of the similar lesions. On elaborating the history, it was found that the patient developed the nodules after 35 years of age. What is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution: Reference:Rook's textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 78

questions.text: A 10-year-old female, living in a rural area presented to the skin OPD with the hairless patch area over the scalp. Which bed side investigation will be useful in this patient to differentiate the species?
questions.solution:
The first use of Wood's lamp was for the detection of tinea capitis based on the fact that some dermatophyte species produce characteristic fluorescence under UV light. The chemical responsible for the fluorescence is pteridine.

  • It can help to diagnose, assess the length and response to treatment; the end point being emergence of non-fluorescent hair.
  • Dermatophytes that cause fluorescence are generally members of theMicrosporum

However, the absence of fluorescence does not necessarily rule out tinea capitis as mostTrichophytonspecies, with the exception ofT. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent.

Reference:Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna,5th edition

questions.text: The nevi shown in the following image occurs along the following lines?
questions.solution:
• The above image shows epidermal nevus occurring along the lines of blaschko.
  • The lines of Blaschko were described by Alfred Blaschko (1858-1922) in 1901.
  • They represent a pattern assumed by many different nevoid and acquired skin diseases on the human skin and mucosae.
  • These lines do not correspond to any known nervous, vascular, or lymphatic structure but represent the developmental growth pattern of the skin.
  • Several congenital conditions such as incontinentiapigmenti, Menkes syndrome, Conradi-Hunermann syndrome, Hypomelanosis of Ito, and acquired conditions such as lichen striatus segmental vitiligo, linear lichen planu;etc. follow Blaschko's lines.
  • The pattern of Blaschko's lines shows V-shape over the upper spine, S-shape on the abdomen, and inverted U-shape from the breast area onto the upper arm. There are perpendicular lines down the front and back of the lower extremities.

Reference: Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna,5th edition

choices.text: A specific sign of subungual melanoma
Longitudinal melanonychia extending on the nail folds
Reflection of pigmentation of nail bed
Reflection of pigmentation of nail matrix

questions.text: Hutchinson sign:
questions.solution:
• Congenital nevi may also exhibit signs of malignancy, such as the Hutchinson sign and progressive darkening and thickening of the nail band.
  • Pseudo-Hutchison's sign is a reflection of the pigmentation of nail bed and nail matrix through the transparent nail folds, whereas Hutchinson's sign is a feature of subungual melanoma where brown-black pigmentation from longitudinal melanonychia extends onto the proximal and lateral nail folds.

Reference:Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna,5th edition

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Micaceous scale (Silvery)

Describes a silvery, white, parakeratotic, lamellated scale. Silvery white appearance is due to reflection of light at the air-keratin interface between the layers of scale. Example: Psoriasis vulgaris

Collarette scale

Describes the fine, peripherally attached and centrally detached scale at the edge of salmon-coloured patch/plaque. Examples: Pityriasis rosea, subsiding lesions of furuncle, miliaria, erythema nodosum, etc

Reference:Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna, 5th edition

choices.text: Deeper fungal infection in which fungi surround degenerate hair shafts
Necrotizing granuloma seen in infectious diseases, such as tuberculosis
Non-necrotizing granuloma seen in diseases such as sarcoidosis
Palisaded histiocytic granulomatous process with central fibrin, seen in rheumatoid nodule

questions.text: What is a Majocchi granuloma?
questions.solution:
Majocchi granuloma is a deep fungal infection involving hair follicles caused by dermatophytes, such asT. rubrum

Reference:Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna,5th edition

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presented with the recurrent attacks of the targetoid lesions on the palms and back. Which of the following infections is not a cause of the same?
questions.solution: Reference:Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 82

choices.text: 'Melanoma develops when keratinocytes mutate in the stratum germinativum.'
'Melanoma of the skin originates from melanocytes found in the stratum basale.'
'Melanoma only occurs on the skin and is the most aggressive type of skin cancer.'
'Melanoma arises from the squamous cells in the stratum spinosum.'

questions.text: Which statement is true regarding the pathophysiology of melanoma?
questions.solution:
This is the only correct statement about melanoma. It can occur anywhere in the body where there are melanocytes (example: middle layer of the eyes (uvea), epidermis etc.) and it originates from the melanocytes.

Reference:Rooks textbook of Dermatology chapter 117

questions.text: Which of the following syndromes is not associated with hemangioma?
questions.solution:
• Facial segmental haemangioma

Posterior fossa malformations,haemangiomas, arterial anomalies,cardiac anomalies, eye abnormalities,sternal pit/supraumbilical raphe(PHACES association)

  • Lower body segmental haemangioma

Lower body IH, uro-genitalanomalies, ulceration, myelopathy,bony deformities, ano-rectalmalformations, arterial anomalies andrenal anomalies (LUMBAR association)

  • Spinal dysraphism, ano-genitalanomalies, cutaneous anomalies,renal and urological anomalies,lumbosacral IH (SACRAL association)
  • Perineal IH, externalgenitalia, malformations,lipo-myelomeningocele, vesico-renalabnormalities, imperforate anus(PELVIS association)

Reference:Rooks textbook of Dermatology chapter 117

questions.text: A 72 year old male presents with multiple grouped vesicles over the erythematous base in T3 dermatome region of trunk. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
• Herpes zoster infection presents in dermatomal fashion.
  • The typical lesions are multiple grouped vesicles over the erythematous base.
  • The lesions are extremely painful and burning.
  • Treatment of choice is tab acyclovir 800mg five times a day with supportive treatment.

Reference:Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna,5th edition

questions.text: A 25 year old female, presents to you with complaints of weal over the trunk and legs. She is a typist and develops similar episodes when she eats spicy food or gets angry. What is she suffering from?
questions.solution:
• The above patient has cholinergic urticaria.
  • The characteristic small and pruritic wheals in cholinergic urticaria appear following any stimulus that induces sweating, including elevation of body temperature, physical exercise, intake of spicy food and emotional stress.

Reference: Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna, 5th edition

questions.text: A 20 year old male presents with rash which has been present for about 4 weeks and is mild itchy. A KOH mount is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
P rosea is a self-limiting papulo-squamous illness with questionable etiology, viral.

The image shows the herald patch.

However, not all P Rosea have herald patch.

Variants of P Rosea include:

  • Inverse Prosea
  • Atypical Prosea ( without hereald
  • P rosea with multiple herald parches
  • Lichenoid, papulovesicular, vesiculobullous variants.

Reference: Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna, 5th edition

questions.text: the above cream is used in the treatment of:
questions.solution:
• Imiquimod is FDA-approved for the treatment of external anogenital warts, actinic keratoses, and superficial basal cell carcinomas.
  • Imiquimod's 5% cream formulation resulted in a statistically significant improvement in treatment effectiveness for external anogenital warts compared with a vehicle cream

Reference:Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna, 5th edition

choices.text: The condition is caused due to blockage of eccrine glands
The condition is caused due to blockage of apocrine glands
Diagnosis of this patient is fox Fordyce disease
It is caused due to the presence of ectopic sebaceous glands

questions.text: A 23-year-old male comes to you with asymptomatic lesion over the lips. On examination, you find pin sized discrete yellow-colored maculopapular lesions over the upper lips. Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
• Fordyce spots are normal large, superficial sebaceous glands seen on the moist tissue that lines some organs and body cavities (mucosal surfaces).
  • The 'spots' are asymptomatic and can be found on the head of the penis, the inner foreskin, and, most commonly, at the border of the lips.
  • These sebaceous glands are not associated with hair follicles. These lesions are asymptomatic, but itching or irritation may occur.

Reference: Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna, 5th edition

questions.text: A family of 5 presents to you with severe itching in the web-spaces with night exacerbation. Which among the following is not a treatment for this condition?
questions.solution: Reference:Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna, 5th edition

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy came with these asymptomatic lesions over the dorsum of hands, elbows and shaft of penis. You provide reassurance to the mother, but she insists on the confirmation of diagnosis by skin biopsy.What is the expected histopathology finding?
questions.solution:
Claw Clutching Ball Appearance

  • The histological appearance of lichen nitidus is commonly referred to as ball and claw configuration for the infiltrate and epidermis, respectively.
  • The ball is comprised of well-circumscribed granulomatous infiltrate composed of lymphocytes, epithelioid cells and occasional Langhans giant cells that are clutched by surrounding hyperplastic rete ridges, giving the overall 'claw clutching ball' appearance.
  • Similar resemblance can be seen in histology of early lesions of juvenile xanthogranuloma (JXG) and lichenoid eruptive histiocytoma. Occasionally, micropapular lichen planus and tuberculoid leprosy may show such appearance, although with shorter 'claws.'

Reference:Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna, 5th edition

questions.text: Choose the correct order on the basis of level of obstruction of eccrine sweat gland duct. (Superficial to deep)
questions.solution:
• Milaria crystalina: blockage at the level of stratum corneum
  • Milaria rubra: blockage below the level of stratum corneum
  • Milaria profunda: blockage at the level of dermo epidermal junction

Reference:Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna, 5th edition

questions.text: Which of the following drugs are not implicated in the causation of Steven Johnson syndrome?
questions.solution: Reference:Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna, 5th edition

questions.text: A 28-year-old female, case of plaque psoriasis develops exacerbation during second trimester of pregnancy. As her treating dermatologist, which drug will you prefer to control the exacerbation?
questions.solution:
• Ciclosporin (cyclosporine) is an immunosuppressive drug first approved for use in organ transplantation to prevent rejection.
  • Ciclosporin is also known to be used for the treatment of psoriasis, rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus and inflammatory bowel disease, among other indications.
  • While it is recommended that all medications that are not absolutely necessary should be avoided during pregnancy, this may not be an option for many women whose quality of life is significantly impacted without treatment, or for those who must continue immunosuppressive therapy to avoid organ rejection.

Reference:Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 51.23

questions.text: Which of the following belongs to first generation of retinoids?
questions.solution: Reference:Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 51.23

questions.text: A 40-year-old male, known case of psoriasis since 20 years. Being fed up of chronic disease and doctor shopping he started self-medicating himself with systemic steroids. After few weeks, the pharmacist denied him to give steroids without prescription. Which of the following complications this man could land up due to withdrawal of steroids?
questions.solution:
Von zumbach disease is a name given to generalized pustular psoriasis.

The withdrawal of systemic steroids in psoriasis leads to pustular psoriasis.

Reference:Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 51.23

questions.text: Choose the correct pair
questions.solution:
• Keratohyalin granules are typically present in the stratum granulosum of the epidermal layer of the skin (and epithelium of the mucosae).
  • KHG are protein structures found in the keratinocytes of the stratum granulosum that appear in two main variants.
  • Globular KHG are found in quickly dividing epithelia, such as the oral mucosa; whereas, stellate KHG are in the slowly dividing normal epidermis.
  • The granules typically contain a mixture of keratin filament bundles, as well as the filament-associated proteins loricrin, filaggrin, and trichohyalin

Reference:Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 51.23

questions.text: Which of the following can cause cicatricial as well as non-cicatricial alopecia?
questions.solution:
SLE can cause both scarring and non-scarring alopecia.

Non scarring alopecia seen in SLE:

  • Telogen effluvium: most common, seen in 60%
  • Lupus hair: seen in chronic cases, patient develops dry, fragile hair along the peripheral hair line during a systemic flare
  • Alopecia areata: seen in 10% patients

Reference:Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 51.23

choices.text: A score of >=10 is required for classifying as SLE
Immunological criteria is a part of additive criteria for SLE

questions.text: Which of the following is false about EULAR criteria (2019) for SLE ?
questions.solution: Reference : EULAR criteria for SLE 2019

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has recurrent multiple asymptomatic ovals and circular faintly hypopigmented macules present over the face. What is next best step?
questions.solution:
The above question depicts Pityriasis alba.

The parents are generally anxious that this hypopigmented macules may not turn into Vitiligo or leprosy. Hence reassurance is the key.

Reference:Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna, 5th edition

choices.text: Do a skin biopsy for confirmation of diagnosis
Start syrup acyclovir as soon as possible
Chemical cautery is treatment of choice

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl has asymptomatic pearly white dome shaped papules present over the forehead. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
• Asymptomatic pearly white papules on a 2-year-old girl is a characteristic of molluscum contagiosum.
  • There is no need of any blood or tissue investigation.
  • It is self-limiting, preferred treatment is chemical cauterization.

Reference:Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna,5th edition

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with itchy lesion over the flexor aspects of bilateral arms since 3 months. New lesions appear on the site of trauma. Which of the following disease show similar phenomenon?
questions.solution:
• New lesions appearing on the site of trauma similar in morphology to previous lesion is called as isomorphic phenomenon/Koebner's phenomenon
  • Perforating dermatoses is a rare disease where Koebner's phenomenon is seen

Reference:Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna, 5th edition

questions.text: Skin biopsy from the nodule over lumbar spine of a newborn reveals a lipoma. What would be your next appropriate step?
questions.solution:
Imaging study

Cutaneous lesions along the midline of spine might give an important clue to the diagnosis of underlying neural tube defect. Clues to the diagnosis include a tuft of hair, lipoma, midline dimple, or vascular lesion. In these instances, imaging studies should be promptly initiated.

Reference:Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna, 5th edition

questions.text: A patient is suspected to have pure neuritic Hansen. You are told to evaluate the nerves of facial region. Which among the following are are palpated as a part of leprosy examination?
questions.solution:
• Pure neuritic Hansen is a distinct entitiy in Indian Classification.
  • There are no well-definedhypoesthetic/erythematous patches.
  • There is diffuse loss of sensation. Multiple nerves are involved.
  • Cutaneous nerves of face palpated in Hansens : supra trochlear, supra orbital nerve, infra orbital, greater auricular and facial nerve.

Reference:Chapter 2.2. In Scollard DM, Gillis TP (ed), International textbook of leprosy

choices.text: Avoid systemic steroids as they cause fetal growth retardation
MDT should be stopped in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 27 year old female pregnant patient, on MDT 2 nd packet comes to you with neuritis. What will be your next best step?
questions.solution:
• There is no need to stop MDT in pregnancy.
  • Thalidomide is contraindicated in pregnancy as it is teratogenic
  • Hence, prednislone is the treatment of choice.

Reference:Chapter 4 In Scollard DM, Gillis TP (ed), International textbook of leprosy

choices.text: Any of the above as all terms are synonymous

questions.text: Match the following per se leprosy
questions.solution:
• Impairments (I code), concerned with abnormalities of body structure and appearance and with organ or system function) resulting from any cause; in principle, impairments represent disturbances at the organ level.
  • Disabilities (D code), reflecting the consequences of impairment in terms of functional performance and activity by the individual; disabilities thus represent disturbances at the level of the person
  • Handicaps (H code), concerned with the disadvantages experienced by the individual as a result of impairments and disabilities; handicaps thus reflect interaction with and adaptation to the individual's surroundings.

Reference:Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna, 5th edition

questions.text:
A 5 month old girl is brought to the hospital by her parents for evaluation of a skin lesion on her buttock. Her parents initially noticed a red macule several weeks after her birth and thought it was an insect bite. They have been applying hydrocortisone cream but the lesion has enlarged, especially over the last 2 months. The skin lesion is shown in the image below.

Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Haemangioma is the commonest vascular tumor in childhood.
  • The etiopathogenesis of haemangioma of infancy remained surrounded by speculations and beliefs.
  • Galen, the Greek physician, thought emotions of the mother to be the cause of vascular birthmark.
  • The term 'angioma' was designated by Virchow to refer to all vascular anomalies.
  • The word 'haemangioma' is derived from the Greek word haima, meaning blood. Haemangiomas are defined as benign neoplasms composed of proliferative and hyperplastic vascular endothelium.
  • They exhibit rapid postnatal growth followed by slow involution, often leading to complete regression.

Reference:Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna, 5th edition

questions.text: A 22 year old woman comes to the office due to a skin disorder. The patient has a 5 year history of patchy depigmentation primarily affecting the hands, feet and face. Some of her lesions have resolved, but overall she has experienced a slowly progressive course. There is no history of pain, itching and erythema. Examination is otherwise normal. Which of the following disease is most likely associated with this patients condition?
questions.solution:
The patient discussed in the question is Vitiligo.

It is associated with other autoimmune disorders like:

  • Addison's disease
  • Hashimoto thyroiditis
  • Type 1 DM

Reference:Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna,5th edition

choices.text: IM penicillin G benzathine 2.4 million units once
IV penicillin G aqueous 18-24 million units daily for 10 to 14 days.
IV penicillin G benzathine 2.4 million units once weekly for 3 weeks
IV penicillin G aqueous 18-24 million units daily for 10 to 14 days.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of a rash on her face and extremities. She states that the rash has been present for the last two months. It was initially raised and discoloured but now has begun to ulcerate. She used to work as a commercial sex worker, up until three years ago. She was diagnosed as HIV positive six months back. She is VDRL positive. Which of the following is an appropriate treatment for this patient's cutaneous lesions?
questions.solution:
• Primary, secondary, or early latent syphilis is treated with a single dose of intramuscular (IM) penicillin G benzathine 2.4 million units. Alternative therapies include doxycycline 100 mg orally (PO) twice daily for 14 days or ceftriaxone 1 to 2 gm IM or intravenously (IV) daily for 10 to 14 days or tetracycline 100 mg PO 4 times for 14 days.
  • Late latent syphilis is treated with IM penicillin G benzathine 2.4 million units once weekly for 3 weeks. Alternative therapies include doxycycline 100 mg PO twice daily for 28 days or tetracycline 100 mg PO four times daily for 28 days.
  • Tertiary syphilis is treated with IM penicillin G benzathine 2.4 million units once weekly for 3 weeks.

Reference:Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna, 5th edition

questions.text: A young married female presents to you with ulcers over the labia majora with burning and pain since 3 days. She has a history of regular unprotected intercourse with her husband, last one week ago. Choose the correct statement about the treatment of choice.
questions.solution:
• Acyclovir is a prodrug that is used to treat herpes simplex and chicken pox. It inhibits DNA synthesis and viral replication after it is converted to acyclovir triphosphate by cellular enzymes. It is a synthetic purine nucleoside analog with in vitro and in vivo inhibitory activity against herpes simplex virus types 1 (HSV-1), 2 (HSV-2), and varicella-zoster virus (VZV).
  • It has a short half-life and, consequently, has to be taken at least four to six times a day.
  • As an antiviral drug, its activity is modest. If given 24 hours after symptoms, it rarely works.

Reference:Wolverton dermatology therapeutics 4 th edition part 1, 332

questions.text: A 36 year old woman presents with a 4 month history of a non-pruritic rash on the chest and arms that worsens with sun exposure. On examination, there is no other rash, no oral ulcer. Labs show no abnormal results except positive ANA and anti - Ro/SSa antibodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The systemic lupus erythematosus lesions have a characteristic distribution with either papulosquamous lesions or annular lesions with central clearing.
  • These two forms can occur concurrently, and the lesions typically heal without atrophy or scarring.
  • The patient may have hypopigmentation or telangiectasia, but in most patients, the skin returns to normal.
  • Patients with SCLE frequently have a mild illness with musculoskeletal complaints and serologic abnormalities.
  • SCLE has a predilection for sun-exposed areas like neck, shoulders, chest, and extensor surfaces of the arms and usually spares the face.

Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology 9thediton chapter 81

choices.text: Epidermis is derived from the endoderm
Stratum spinosum contains actively dividing stem cells
The epidermis over the whole body comprises of 5 layers
The intercellular connection in the epidermis are called as desmosomes.

questions.text: Find out the correct statement relating to the structure of the skin.
questions.solution:
• Epidermis is derived from the ectoderm
  • Stratum basale contains actively dividing stem cells
  • The epidermis over the palm and soles comprises of 5 layers

Reference:Illustrated textbook of Dermatology, Neena Khanna, 5th edition

choices.text: Mainly seen from the cases hailing from Russia

questions.text: True about lucio phenomena :
questions.solution:
• Lucio's phenomenon is a complication of diffuse non-nodular LL
  • It doesn't respond to thalidomide. It resolves on its own in 15 days. Generally MDT is the treatment of choice.
  • MEDINA test: the test is similar to lepromin except that antigen is prepared from the lesion of lucio leprosy.

Reference:Chapter 2.2. In Scollard DM, Gillis TP (ed), International textbook of leprosy

choices.text: Foamy appearance is due to bacilli
Bacilli are present in tetrads in these macrophages

questions.text: True about macrophages of lepromatous leprosy :
questions.solution:
• In macrophages of lepromatous leprosy, bacilli undergo intracellular multiplication to form bundles and clumps.
  • Lipid containing vacuoles develp in the cytoplasm to give foamy appearance
  • Foam cell was first described by Virchow, hence called Virchow cells.

Reference:Chapter 2.2. In Scollard DM, Gillis TP (ed), International textbook of leprosy

questions.text: Ventral pterygium of nail is seen :
questions.solution:
Ventral pterygium: extension of hyponychium to nail plate, thereby hampering the nail growth.

Seen in :

Leprosy

SLE

Subungual exostosis

Neurofibromatosis

Systemic sclerosis

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9thediton chapter 81

questions.text: A 45 year old heterosexual man presented painful ulcers on his penis for 10 days. An enlarged tender lymph node was present on left side, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Typically, an erythematous papule develops at the site of inoculation, which quickly becomes a pustule and subsequently develops into an extremely painful ulcer with soft irregular margins, often referred to as a 'soft chancre.'
  • Multiple ulcers may be noted either as a result of multiple areas of microtrauma or as a result of direct contact between two adjacent areas resulting in 'Kissing ulcers.'
  • The ulcer typically has a friable base with yellow-gray exudate, which easily bleeds when abraded and varies in size, typically from 1 to 2 cm. Left untreated, the lesion spontaneously resolves within 1 to 3 months

Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 30

questions.text: The common sites for the formation of chancre are the glans penis or the underside of prepuce. However, if the chancre occurs on the hilt or base of the penis, it is called:
questions.solution:
• Condom chancre: occurs in those wearing condoms, the site is root of penis or hilt
  • Chancre redux: the recurrence of chancre at the site of healed chancre during secondary stage
  • Pseudo chancre redux: is a gumma appearing at the site of original chancre
  • Concealed chancre: intracervical or intra meatal chancre

Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 29

questions.text: Most common cause of cutaneous TB is.
questions.solution: Lupus vulgaris is the commonest cause of cutaneous TB

questions.text: A12 year old boy presented with a lesion over his right buttock which had peripheral scaling and central clearing with scarring. What will be the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
• The above description matches lupus vulgaris.
  • It is the commonest cause of cutaneous tb.
  • Most common site of lupus vulgaris: buttocks
  • Hence, investigation of choice is skin biopsy.

Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 27

questions.text: A 17-year-old female presents to the clinic for painful swelling and ulceration of her left index finger. She states that she injured her finger on a fishing trip with her family three weeks ago. It started as a small tender nodule on the tip of her finger and progressed to a large ulcerated lesion with subsequent swelling of the digit. Examination of the hand reveals a granulomatous, ulcerated, suppurative lesion with tense edema of the entire digit. Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The above situation is fish tank granuloma.
  • This is caused by Mycobacterium marinum
  • It is an atypical mycobacteria, classified as a rapid grower ( Runyons classification)

Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 27

questions.text: A 45 year old farmer comes to skin OPD with painful swollen foot, which has discharging sinuses and black coloured grains coming out of the sinuses. What is the most appropriate clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario talks about a deep fungal infection, mycetoma.

The clinical triad of mycetoma:

Granules

Swelling

Sinuses

The black granules confirms it is eumycetoma - Madura foot.

Reference:Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 32

questions.text: Bullous pemphigoid is a chronic autoimmune skin disorder that occurs more often in patients > 60 years of age. Which of the following is the most common initial symptom?
questions.solution:
Bullous Pemphigoid is a chronic autoimmune disorder

Seen in 6th decade onwards

Pre bullous stage presents with severe pruritus

It is followed by formation of tense bullae.

Reference:Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 27

choices.text: Has marked sensitivity to UV light

questions.text: All are true about Xeroderma Pigmentosa Except:
questions.solution:
XP is an autosomal recessive inherited disorder of DNA repair

  • The median onset of the cutaneous symptoms is between ages one and two years.
  • These abnormalities are limited to sun-exposed areas.
  • Continued sun exposure causes the skin to become dry and parchment-like with increased pigmentation; hence the name xeroderma pigmentosum ('dry pigmented skin').
  • Most individuals with XP develop xerosis (dry skin) and poikiloderma (the constellation of hyper- and hypopigmentation, atrophy, and telangiectasia).
  • Premalignant actinic keratoses develop at an early age.
  • XP is an example of accelerated photoaging. The appearance of sun-exposed skin in children with XP is similar to that occurring in farmers and sailors after many years of extreme sun exposure

choices.text: Infective eczema: caused by microorganism or their products
Infected eczema: eczema complicated by secondary bacterial or viral infection

questions.text: True about eczema:
questions.solution:
Eczema is a form of dermatitis,

  • g., of infected eczema:

Eczema herpeticum: atopic dermatitis complicated by herpes simplex infection

  • g., of infective eczema:

A pustule ruptures and contents of pustule cause eczema in the surrounding skin

Reference:Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter

questions.text: Which of the following factor is implicated in etiology of ingrown toe nails?
questions.solution:
The factors implicated in ingrown toe nails are:

  • Ill-fitting footwear
  • Trauma
  • Improper cutting of nails
  • Anatomical abnormalities of nail
  • Nail infections
  • Hyperhidrosis

Reference:Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 95
